IOPn @IOPn_io æ–°ç­”é¢˜ä»»åŠ¡å¯é¢†å– $OPN æµ‹è¯•å¸å¥–åŠ±ï¼Œç­”é¢˜æ¯”è¾ƒç®€å•
https://learn.iopn.tech
é¢†æ°´é“¾æ¥ï¼šhttps://faucet.iopn.tech

How does IOPn describe the starting point for digital sovereignty?
Answer: Controlling your identity with one credential, your rules, everywhere

What is the fundamental difference between current systems and IOPn's approach?
Answer: Current systems are optimized for extraction; IOPn is built for empowerment

What does IOPn mean by "sovereign infrastructure"?
Answer: Infrastructure where you control your identity, assets, and future

Who is affected by the current lack of digital ownership?
Answer: Individuals, businesses, and governments

What does "Internet of People" represent in IOPn's vision?
Answer: A network where infrastructure serves people, not platforms

According to IOPn's vision, who currently controls your digital identity?
Answer: The platforms you use

What is the core problem IOPn addresses?
Answer: Lack of ownership over digital identity, data, and accounts

item.title: Transcriptï¼š â€”â€” Role: You are now my Technical Co-Founder. Your job is to help me build a real product I can use, share, or launch. Handle all the b...
item.description:
Transcriptï¼š
â€”â€”
Role:
You are now my Technical Co-Founder. Your job is to help me build a real product I can use, share, or launch. Handle all the building, but keep me in the loop and in control.

My Idea:
[Describe your product idea â€” what it does, who it's for, what problem it solves. Explain it like you'd tell a friend.]

How serious I am:
[Just exploring / I want to use this myself / I want to share it with others / I want to launch it publicly]

Project Framework:

1. Phase 1: Discovery
â€¢ Ask questions to understand what I actually need (not just what I said)
â€¢ Challenge my assumptions if something doesn't make sense
â€¢ Help me separate "must have now" from "add later"
â€¢ Tell me if my idea is too big and suggest a smarter starting point

2. Phase 2: Planning
â€¢ Propose exactly what we'll build in version 1
â€¢ Explain the technical approach in plain language
â€¢ Estimate complexity (simple, medium, ambitious)
â€¢ Identify anything I'll need (accounts, services, decisions)
â€¢ Show a rough outline of the finished product

3. Phase 3: Building
â€¢ Build in stages I can see and react to
â€¢ Explain what you're doing as you go (I want to learn)
â€¢ Test everything before moving on
â€¢ Stop and check in at key decision points
â€¢ If you hit a problem, tell me the options instead of just picking one

4. Phase 4: Polish
â€¢ Make it look professional, not like a hackathon project
â€¢ Handle edge cases and errors gracefully
â€¢ Make sure it's fast and works on different devices if relevant
â€¢ Add small details that make it feel "finished"

5. Phase 5: Handoff
â€¢ Deploy it if I want it online
â€¢ Give clear instructions for how to use it, maintain it, and make changes
â€¢ Document everything so I'm not dependent on this conversation
â€¢ Tell me what I could add or improve in version 2

6. How to Work with Me
â€¢ Treat me as the product owner. I make the decisions, you make them happen.
â€¢ Don't overwhelm me with technical jargon. Translate everything.
â€¢ Push back if I'm overcomplicating or going down a bad path.
â€¢ Be honest about limitations. I'd rather adjust expectations than be disappointed.
â€¢ Move fast, but not so fast that I can't follow what's happening.

Rules:
â€¢ I don't just want it to work â€” I want it to be something I'm proud to show people
â€¢ This is real. Not a mockup. Not a prototype. A working product.
â€¢ Keep me in control and in the loop at all times


Miles Deutscher:â€‚Alright - here's my most powerful vibe coding prompt ever.

Plug this straight into the new Opus 4.6 model, and you'll literally be able to ship anything.

SEO optimised websites, fully functional Claude apps, personal dashboards - literally anything.

Takes <5 minutes:

item.title: RT wishful_cynic: Re I don't think it's a problem per se . I don't think I've seen any strong evidence to suggest market crashes happen because of 1+2...
item.description:
RTâ€‚wishful_cynic
Re I don't think it's a problem per se . I don't think I've seen any strong evidence to suggest market crashes happen because of 1+2+3 (and I would also put ADLs in a different bucket altogether cause it's mostly cex vs MM pvp, nothing to do with market moves).

I think generally crypto cex model wont necessarily stand the test of time, but it has more to do with the tradfi model being superior (and this criticism applies to similarly)

item.title: Thereâ€™s an endless flood of shitposts claiming that crypto is dead. In reality, this is just another very typical cycle ğŸ”„ Every cycle looks termin...
item.description:
Thereâ€™s an endless flood of shitposts claiming that crypto is dead.
In reality, this is just another very typical cycle ğŸ”„

Every cycle looks terminal when youâ€™re living inside it. What most people fail to notice is that real infrastructure is still being built, even in the worst market conditions.

This cycle alone, weâ€™ve already seen genuinely important innovations:

- Platforms like Hyperliquid and Polymarket have turned global, permissionless gambling and speculation into reality â€” giving access to offshore derivatives and prediction markets that are otherwise heavily restricted in the US and EU.

- At the same time, the rise of TradFi perps on CEXs and HIP3 is quietly expanding access to global financial assets.
Third World People in regions where opening a brokerage account is nearly impossible can now trade the same companies that used to be reserved for developed markets. Few understand this opens a portal to billions of users.

Crypto isnâ€™t shrinking as itâ€™s eating market shares from two Trillion-Dollar territory : TradFi and online casinos.

The number of people who can gain exposure to speculative markets keeps increasing. When sentiment flips, liquidity will come back.

Meanwhile, the purge is finally happening.
Shitty VC coins, useless stupid â€œgovernance tokensâ€, dead af protocols with no cash flow. Theyâ€™re not coming back. They just go down â€” and thatâ€™s healthy.

Valuations are compressing toward levels that are actually sustainable. Protocols with real revenue are starting to be essential and gain attention from entire market.

This isnâ€™t the end of crypto.

Itâ€™s the part of the cycle where weak hands, weak narratives, and weak balance sheets get wiped out.

Fasten your seatbelt.
Survive.
And be ready for the next great cycle of gambling and speculation.

Because it always comes back.
